body: Q. I own and live in a co-op in Brooklyn and have had great stress over the years regarding the unit next to mine. The unit is owned by a nonresident shareholder who sublets it to anyone he wants without board approval. The managing agent told me that only if this particular nonresident shareholder had once lived in his unit would he have to have
title: Q. & A.; Board Approval to Sublet a Co-op

body: Gardeners are intimate with the cycle of life, death and rebirth. But a different kind of renewal, both cultural and horticultural, is taking place at the Brooklyn Botanic Garden. Some 80 declining Norway maples, originally planted to commemorate the end of World War I and scheduled to be replaced, will soon make room for a grove of scarlet oaks
title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: PROSPECT HEIGHTS; Maples Planted for an Old War Make Way for a New Shrine

body: To the Editor: Re ''To Add to Wall Street's Woes, Riders Must Wait for Limousines'' (Nov. 11): Unmentioned was the air pollution generated by idling black cars. Regardless of the season, engines are left on while drivers chat on the sidewalk, often with windows open, so they can't claim that they're heating or cooling the interiors. The city
title: Double-Parked Limousines Are Also a Pollution Issue

body: There had been predictions of mayhem: broken machines, overwhelming lines, Florida-like chaos. But when voters finally made it to the polls yesterday for the city's general election, they found only a few sporadic glitches. The most serious seemed to be the ballot itself, which left many voters struggling, behind the curtains, to locate levers
title: THE 2001 ELECTIONS: THE VOTING; Confusion, but It Was No Florida

body: Challenging traditional thinking about political participation in New York City, the gap between white and Hispanic turnout narrowed in the mayoral primary election two weeks ago, a new analysis of voting patterns has shown. In City Council districts that are largely made up of whites of non-Hispanic descent, voter turnout was among the highest in
title: Hispanics Near Whites in Voter Turnout, Study Says

body: AMY DUBOIS BARNETT, the editor in chief of Honey magazine, is remarkably composed on a recent afternoon, particularly given that her computer ate every word of her essay on Aaliyah, the young pop singer who died in an August plane crash in the Bahamas. The editor is closing the November tribute issue to Aaliyah. Things are a bit insane. But Ms.
title: PUBLIC LIVES; The New Face of Honey, Creating Some Buzz

body: The primary election scheduled for Sept. 11 but postponed because of the terrorist attack will be held today. Absentee ballots submitted before Sept. 11 count, but votes cast at polling places that day do not. This list summarizes The Times's recommendations in some primary races throughout New York City and Nassau County. All are Democratic
title: Voting Today in New York

body: SHE refuses to remove her scarf. But Efrah, a Muslim woman who lives in Prospect Heights, Brooklyn, is still afraid because she has heard stories of women in hijab (Arabic for veil) who have been attacked and called names. It was Efrah's fear that made her ask that her last name not be given in this column. She will not ride a subway or a bus. And
title: COPING; Trying to Soothe The Fears Hiding Behind the Veil

body: The New York Is Book Country fair, which was to be held on Sunday on Fifth Avenue, has been canceled because of the terrorist attacks. But a variety of book-related activities, including screenings, readings and panel discussions, are still planned at museums, libraries and elsewhere in New York City this weekend. Information on events:
title: Speaking of Books: Weekend Events

body: Still a Symbol Of Hope Many musicals have been written about famous people, but it's rare that a celebrity subject has what amounts to a front-row seat at every performance. That's just what will happen tomorrow and next Saturday, though, when Theater Garden, a producer of educational plays for children, is to present ''Lady of Copper'' on a barge
title: FAMILY FARE

body: The garage bay in Rescue 1's station house is empty, and many coat hooks are unused. But the ladder truck and some men's overcoats are the extent of the losses the station's remaining men will concede. Their brothers, the 11 who ran into the World Trade Center and have yet to come out, are nothing more than ''unaccounted for.'' ''With this job, you
title: AFTER THE ATTACKS: THE FIREHOUSES; A Growing Realization of an Unspeakable Loss

title: FAMILY FARE

title: On the Bus

body: A Revolution In Brooklyn New Yorkers may think of their city as a battlefield, but many years have passed since it's been literally one. Tomorrow and Sunday, though, parts of Brooklyn will take on the look of a military campaign, with musket smoke as well as smog clogging the air, and booming cannons competing with the traffic noise. The occasion
title: FAMILY FARE

title: Judge Grants Couple's Wish For Mercy

body: LIKE most of us, Ann Hamman is deluged with mail offering ''preapproved'' credit cards and various lines of credit from banks and financial services companies, large and small. title: SENIORITY; A Special Invitation (to Anyone)

body: The Amy Watkins murder case came to an end yesterday with the conviction of a 21-year-old Brooklyn man on second-degree murder charges. The defendant, Felix Rodriguez, was the lookout when another man plunged a knife into the back of Ms. Watkins, a young social worker from Kansas, during a robbery on a dark Brooklyn street in March 1999,
title: Second Defendant Is Convicted in 1999 Murder of Social Worker

body: A Brooklyn man who was wrongly jailed for 11 years and then freed was arrested yesterday in the rape and robbery of a woman in her Prospect Heights home last month. The police charged the man, Timothy Crosby, 40, with rape, robbery, burglary and criminal possession of a weapon in the May 10 attack on the 26-year-old woman. Investigators identified
title: Man Wrongly Jailed Is Arrested in Rape

body: A judge sentenced a Brooklyn man yesterday to the maximum prison term of 25 years to life for the fatal stabbing of Amy Watkins, a graduate student from Kansas who was killed on her way home from the subway in March 1999. In sentencing the man, David Jamison, in State Supreme Court in Brooklyn, Justice Michael R. Juviler brought to a close a major
title: Maximum Prison Term for Killer of Social Worker

body: Surely one of the most suburban parts of Brooklyn is the wrench-shaped peninsula that holds Bergen Beach, Georgetown, Mill Basin and Old Mill Basin. This area is embroidered with shady, quiet streets and mint-green lawns; down by the water, houses can sell for $1 million and more. Historically, the area has been overwhelmingly white, and remains
title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: SOUTHEAST BROOKLYN; Drops of Diversity in a Quiet Area

body: A 28-year-old man was convicted of second-degree murder yesterday in the death of Amy Watkins, the graduate student who was fatally stabbed during a botched robbery as she walked from the subway to her Brooklyn apartment in March 1999. The random nature of the murder shocked people in New York, countering a growing sense of security that had come
title: Man Convicted in '99 Murder Of Social Worker From Kansas

title: Student's Father Tells Jury of Identifying Her Body

title: Confession in Brooklyn Stabbing Is Ruled Admissable as Evidence

title: Touring Art and History in New York Houses

body: HOMES for boys have a dark reputation going back to ''Oliver Twist'': images of children processed through years of loneliness, neglect and bitter pain. So when men like Stephen Alexander McCain, an associate producer for ''48 Hours'' on CBS, emerge out of the foster-care system whole and even thriving, it bends the cliché into new shapes. Mr.
title: WEDDINGS: VOWS; Karen Palmer and Stephen McCain

title: Midtown Soup Kitchen Serves Its Last

author: Apollinaire Scherr writes on contemporary art and dance for several national magazines.
body: THE six women hang from their heels on a trapeze, balance tree branches on their chins and flip backward through hoops held high, but what they do isn't exactly circus. ''In circus, the premium is on the trick,'' said Sarah East Johnson, artistic director of the Bessie- and Obie-award-winning troupe, Lava, after a vigorous rehearsal in her narrow
title: DANCE; An Acrobatic Work Far From the Circus

body: WEST FARMS Artists Meet to Merge The Visual and the Musical The Bronx River Art Center and Gallery has staged a meeting of minds, musical and visual. The fruits of this labor are on exhibit this month in an installation called the ''Sights and Sounds From the Artist Space Program.'' It features works done in a collaboration between composers and
title: PLAYING IN THE NEIGHBORHOOD

body: From Books To Ballet Dance is hardly a sedentary pursuit. So why does the latest production by the New York Theater Ballet begin and end with an activity that most of us do sitting down? It's because the staging not only brings to life two beloved children's stories, ''The Little Mermaid'' and ''The Nightingale,'' but also emphasizes the pleasures
title: FAMILY FARE

body: SNUG HARBOR Intentional Incongruities From Pairs of Artists Collaboration is common in the performing arts but rarer in the visual arts; a show opening today at the Snug Harbor Cultural Center seeks to shift the balance. Called ''BiFocal,'' it is presented by the Artists' Federation of Staten Island and the Newhouse Center of Contemporary Art.
title: PLAYING IN THE NEIGHBORHOOD
